sections.label: Overview
sections.title: Gentle check-ups with attentive screening
sections.body:
Dental check-ups are not just about teeth. They are an opportunity to assess your overall oral health, identify early changes, and discuss concerns before they become more complex.

As part of a routine examination, we also look for signs of oral cancer and other soft tissue conditions. These checks are visual and hands-on, and are carried out carefully at each visit.

For most people, nothing unusual is found. The value lies in consistency and familiarity — knowing what is normal for you, and noticing when something changes.

sections.label: Check-up steps
sections.title: What happens at a check-up
items: A dental check-up involves examining your teeth, gums, bite, and existing dental work.

We look for early signs of decay, gum disease, wear, or fracture, and assess how restorations are functioning over time. X-rays may be recommended where clinically justified to see areas that cannot be assessed visually.
Time is also set aside to discuss symptoms, habits, or changes you’ve noticed, so care can be tailored rather than routine.

sections.label: Imaging
sections.title: Digital x-rays and imaging
items: Low-dose digital x-rays when clinically indicated
Intraoral photos to track changes and share progress
Guidance on why and when imaging is recommended
Results explained in plain language with time for questions

sections.label: Who it's for
sections.title: Who benefits from regular exams
items: Adults managing fillings, crowns, or implants
Patients with gum sensitivity or dry mouth
Anyone noticing changes in bite, comfort, or soft tissues

sections.label: Frequency
sections.title: How often to book
sections.body: Most people stay on track with 6-monthly visits. If you have higher decay or gum risk, recent treatment, or are in active orthodontic care, we may agree a shorter cadence. We explain any recommendations so you know why timing matters.

sections.label: Support
sections.title: If something is worrying you
sections.body: If you notice ulcers that do not settle, new lumps, persistent soreness, or changes to your mouth or throat, contact us promptly. We will arrange a calm assessment, share what we can see, and signpost to further investigation if needed.

faqs.question: Do I need x-rays every time?
faqs.answer: Not always. We follow clinical guidance and your risk profile to decide when x-rays are useful. We will explain the reason, dose, and what we are looking for before taking them.

faqs.question: Will you tell me if you see anything concerning?
faqs.answer: Yes. We talk you through any changes, explain what is normal, and outline next steps if we spot something that needs a closer look.

faqs.question: How often should I book a check-up?
faqs.answer: The right timing depends on your oral health and risk factors. Many people attend every six months, but some need more frequent visits and others less.

faqs.question: Can I combine a check-up with hygiene?
faqs.answer: Often yes. We can align appointments so you have your check-up and hygiene visit together when schedules allow.

sections.title: Arrange your routine dental check-up
sections.body: Book a calm examination with oral cancer screening included. Tell us if you would like a slower pace or extra reassurance.

primary_intent.label: Plan a clinician-led dental crowns review

secondary_intent.label: Consider alternatives like Tooth wear repairs

reassurance_intent.label: Map next steps such as Root canal therapy

clinical_focus: Full-coverage restorations for cracked and heavily restored teeth
Scan-guided margin and occlusion design for predictable fit
typical_case_type: Posterior teeth following root canal therapy needing reinforcement
Fractured cusps or extensive failing restorations requiring coverage
planning_considerations: Crack mapping, remaining dentine thickness, and parafunctional risk
Material selection matched to aesthetic zone and occlusal load
Bite protection planning, including splinting where indicated
